title: Is It Bronchitis or Pneumonia?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: When a cold or the flu sets in, you probably know how it’s going to unfold. It starts maybe with that scratch in the back of your throat. You start to feel run-down. Next thing you know, you’re parked in front of the television with a box of tissues.
But when it comes to bronchitis and pneumonia , it might be a little harder to know what’s going on and how to tell them apart.
Bronchitis is when your bronchial tubes, which carry air to your lungs , get infected and swollen. There are two kinds:

Pneumonia is another infection in your lungs , but instead of the bronchial tubes, you get it in tiny air sacs in your lungs called alveoli. It can be mild, but sometimes serious, especially for the very young, adults 65 or older, and people with weaker immune systems.
Learn more about these two conditions – see how they are alike and how they are different:
bullets: Acute bronchitis. This lasts a few weeks and usually goes away on its own.
Chronic bronchitis. It’s more serious, and you’re more likely to get it if you smoke. In this article, we’re looking at acute bronchitis.

sections.heading: What Causes Bronchitis?
content: Most often, the same viruses that give you a cold or the flu also cause bronchitis. Sometimes though, bacteria are to blame.
In both cases, as your body fights off the germs, your bronchial tubes swell and produce more mucus. That means you have smaller openings for air to flow, which can make it harder to breathe.

sections.heading: What Causes Pneumonia?
content: Pneumonia can be caused by:
As your body fights off the germs, your lungs’ air sacs swell and may fill with fluid or pus, much like your bronchial tubes swell and fill with mucus when you have bronchitis.
bullets: Mycoplasmas, which are like bacteria and give you milder symptoms (sometimes called “ walking pneumonia ”)
Viruses (the same ones that cause colds and the flu can also give you pneumonia)

sections.heading: Bronchitis Treatments
content: Most of the time, acute bronchitis goes away on its own within a couple of weeks. If it’s bacterial, your doctor may give you antibiotics . If you have asthma , allergies , or you’re wheezing, your doctor may suggest an inhaler.

content: It’s best to avoid cough medicine unless your cough keeps you awake at night. Bringing up mucus actually helps you because it clears the gunk out of your lungs. Avoid giving cough medicine to children younger than 4 years. For children 4 and older, check with your doctor first.
Here are some things you can do to ease your symptoms:
bullets: Drink a lot of water. Eight to 12 glasses a day help thin out your mucus and makes it easier to cough it up.

Take over-the-counter pain relievers with aspirin , ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin ), and naproxen (Aleve) to help with pain, but avoid giving aspirin to children. You can use acetaminophen (Tylenol) to help with pain and fever.
Use a humidifier or try steam to loosen up the mucus; a hot shower can work well.

content: If it’s caused by bacteria, you’ll get an antibiotic. If it’s caused by a virus, you may get an antiviral drug. And if it’s really severe, you may need to go to the hospital, though that’s not as common.

meta_description: Bronchitis and pneumonia are lung infections and can be hard to tell apart. Learn what causes each condition, what their symptoms are, and what you can do to treat them.
